bibl.title: English translation [from Spanish] of letter from Maria Teresa Rojas to Philip Showalter Hench, March 22, 1952

div1.p: Rojas informs Hench that nothing can be predicted in relation to the preservation of Camp Lazear because the political situation is unstable. She discusses visiting with Rath so that he might advise them on the preservation of the San Jose property which has historical links to Camp Lazear. Rojas believes the San Jose property may be of interest to both the United States and Cuba for this reason.

div1.head: English translation [from Spanish] of letter from Maria Teresa Rojas to Philip Showalter Hench, March 22, 1952 (See Spanish original.)
div1.opener:
March 22, 1952
Dr. Philip S. Hench, M. D.
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
My Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
So many and so grave events have happened since the last time we saw each
other that I have not dared to write you, in hopes that the political
picture would clear up a little bit and become more normal. Although
nothing can be predicted yet and in spite of the disastrous effects
that can be occasioned the country by a situation like this, that is, of
not finding a legal way out for it, it would be extremely favorable for
the realization of our plans if Dr. Enrique Saladrigas, the present
Minister of Health, will maintain in his position. You met Dr. Saladrigas
on one of your visits to Havana when he was the director of the Finlay
Institute. Dr. Saladrigas is a great friend of ours and it would be easy
to interest him in our projects concerning Camp Lazear. The Minister of
Public Works, Ing. Jose Mendigutia is also a good friend of ours, and I
am sure that he will give us his cooperation. So we can only desire that
the present government may consolidate itself in a legal form and hope
that all will return to normality before trying to do anything in this
sense.

Thank you very much for all the efforts which you have made in my behalf
with the gentlemen of the National Council for Historic Sites and Buildings.
A few days ago I received a letter from Mr. Frederick L. Rath together with
various explanatory folders of the societies over which he presides. I
would be extremely pleased at the suggestion which you make me that Mr. Rath
might come for 2 or 3 days to Havana, provided that this will not upset his
plans and of course we would lodge him in San Jose with a great deal of
pleasure. I think that on the ground he would be able to appreciate better
the close ties that unite our house with Camp Lazear. Ties that will be
made even more evident with the realization that some of our projects,
destined to point out and to give its true relief to the participation that
the Americans had in everything concerning the investigations and discoveries
dealing with yellow fever which took place here and which has up to now been
so unjustly silenced, and agree with us that for this reason it can be
considered a place of historic interest for the United States as well as
for Cuba. Perhaps then we shall find a solution. As you know my difficulty
in expressing myself in English I should prefer to have you write to him
directly in my name.

I hope that the period of rest has made you feel better and that the
bothersome colds have now passed.

I am writing to Mary, answering her affectionate letter, telling her how
much we miss them, remembering continuously in our conversations the very
agreeable days that we passed together and which I hope we will be able to
repeat before very long. With affectionate regards of Lydia and my cousin
Julia, receive an affectionate greeting from
